description: Introduction to programming and computer science for those with no prior programming experience. Focuses on the basic aspects of programming, with an emphasis on core principles. Labs provide a supportive environment to learn how to program with peers. Weekly discussions will introduce some of the many ways computer science interacts with society. Programming assignments will demonstrate how to use computing in a variety of disciplines. \n
name: How to Program
note: Designed for those with no prior experience in programming

description: Teaches how to design, develop, reason about, and test programs. Topics include higher-order functions, object-oriented programming, recursion, algorithms, data structures, decomposition, interpreters, and regular expressions.
name: Intro to Computer Science

learningOutcomes.objective: Design and develop moderate to medium-sized programs for problems with significant complexity, using both object-oriented and functional paradigms.
learningOutcomes.name: Design
Confidence
learningOutcomes.objective: Demonstrate increased confidence in ability to design, develop, and test programs.

learningOutcomes.name: Algorithms
learningOutcomes.objective: Effectively use basic algorithms to design and develop a program, including recursion.
Use data structures (e.g. lists, dictionaries, linked lists, trees) to organize data in a program.
learningOutcomes.name: Data Structures

learningOutcomes.objective: Independently read documentation for a library, understand its operation, and incorporate the library into a program to extend its functionality.
learningOutcomes.name: Modules & Libraries
Abstraction
learningOutcomes.objective: Effectively use modules, classes, and functions to decompose functionality of a medium-complexity system.

learningOutcomes.name: Testing and Debugging
learningOutcomes.objective: Write unit tests to ensure complete and correct functioning of a program. Explain the meaning of error messages encountered when running a program. Use the debugger in an IDE to step through code execution and identify the source of a bug.

learningOutcomes.name: Computing
learningOutcomes.objective: Write programs to accomplish tasks relevant to computer science, such as data visualization, image processing, network communication, storing and retrieving data from databases, etc.

nonEnforcedPrerequisites: CS 110 or equivalent prior programming experience
recommended: Prior programming experience should include statements, variables, control flow (if/while), and functions

description: Introduction to object-oriented program design and development.  Principles of algorithm formulation and implementation.
name: Intro to Computer Programming

description: This course is a broad, interdisciplinary look at the field of data science, and how to derive insight from data.  It will develop technical skills (including some python programming, statistics, linear algebra, machine learning, data cleaning and visualization) as well as data literacy (mental frameworks for decomposing data science problems, critical thinking about potential conclusions of an analysis, and potential pitfalls of overreliance on unreliable data).
name: Intro to Data Science
nonEnforcedPrerequisites: CS 110 or equivalent prior programming experience
recommended: Prior programming experience should include statements, variables, control flow (if/while), and functions

description: Introduction to the discipline of computer science and its fields. Lectures will provide an accessible introduction to the fields of computer science for those who are new to the discipline.
name: Exploring CS

learningOutcomes.objective: Identify the types of problems that each discipline in CS pursues.
learningOutcomes.name: Problems

learningOutcomes.objective: Explore methods that are used by disciplines in CS by completing small experiential learning projects.
learningOutcomes.name: Methods

learningOutcomes.objective: Create a personalized study plan for a computer science degree.
learningOutcomes.name: Educational Plan

recommended: Recommend during freshman year, first semester after transferring to BYU, first semester after transferring from another major, or while enrolled in CS 110 or CS 111

description: Internships or cooperative education experiences with organizations outside BYU.
name: Academic Internship
note: An APPROVED Internship Application is required before adding.

learningOutcomes.name: Provide Work Experience
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will develop familiarity with industrial software development and analysis.

description: Undergraduate level subjects as announced before each semester.
name: Topics in Computer Science

learningOutcomes.name: Data gathering
learningOutcomes.objective: Because 201R is an experiment course, data on how well the course accomplished the outcomes will be gathered.  This will usually be in the form of surveys, exam scores, and project scores.

learningOutcomes.name: Experimental course
learningOutcomes.objective: A 201R course is used by a professor who is teaching an experimental course.  Learning outcomes will vary for the course, but these outcomes are evaluated during the vetting process (through the department undergraduate curriculum committee) before the professor is allowed to teach the course.  At this level, typical learning outcomes involve computing practice and fundamental theory.

nonEnforcedPrerequisites: Instructor's consent.

description: The first of three experiential learning labs that will provide students with hands-on experience with various tools, technologies, and techniques that software engineers use in practice. In addition to hands-on lab experiences, this course contains lecture and assigned reading content that will provide an understanding of what a software engineering career is and what roles and responsibilities are available to software engineers.
name: Software Engineering Lab 1
note: C S 202, 203, and 204 are designed to be taken in sequence

learningOutcomes.objective: Know what software engineering is. Know the different roles within a software engineering career.
learningOutcomes.name: Definition and roles
UI Design
learningOutcomes.objective: Use a modeling tool to create wireframe and screenflow diagrams to represent a UI design.
Create and understand UML Class, Sequence and Activity diagrams.
learningOutcomes.name: Modeling
Code Reviews
learningOutcomes.objective: Understand what code reviews are and why they are useful.

learningOutcomes.name: Documentation
learningOutcomes.objective: Understand the importance of software documentation and use a tool to generate code level documentation.

learningOutcomes.name: Source Control
learningOutcomes.objective: Understand why source control is needed and gain experience using a source control tool.

learningOutcomes.name: Coding Style
learningOutcomes.objective: Know how to use tools to enforce coding style decisions.

learningOutcomes.name: Debugging
learningOutcomes.objective: Be able to debug software programs, both from the command line and from an IDE using a debugger.

nonEnforcedPrerequisites: With instructor consent, may be taken concurrently with C S 203 and 204.

description: The second of three experiential learning labs that will provide students with hands-on experience with various tools, technologies, and techniques that software engineers use in practice. The lab experiences in this course build on those learned in CS 202 and focus on tools and techniques for source code testing, automated source code analysis, and source code build and dependency management.
name: Software Engineering Lab 2
note: C S 202, 203, and 204 are designed to be taken in sequence.

learningOutcomes.objective: Use static analysis tools to identify and correct potential code problems.  Understand what code profiling is and use a code profiler to identify performance trouble spots in a software program.  Use a testing tool to test application performance.
learningOutcomes.name: Analysis
Management
learningOutcomes.objective: Demonstrate how to use build and dependency management tools to manage a large, complex code base.  Link to Program Outcomes: None

learningOutcomes.name: Testing
learningOutcomes.objective: Understand the basic concepts and approaches used by software engineers to test software.  Use a testing framework to write automated unit tests.  Use a code coverage tool to assess code coverage.

nonEnforcedPrerequisites: With instructor consent, may be taken concurrently with C S 202 and 204.

description: The third of three experiential learning labs that will provide students with hands-on experience with various tools, technologies, and techniques that software engineers use in practice. The lab experiences in this course build on those learned in CS 202 and CS 203 and focus on tools and techniques for cloud development and Agile programming.
name: Software Engineering Lab 3
note: C S 202, 203, and 204 are designed to be taken in sequence.

learningOutcomes.name: Virtual Machines
learningOutcomes.objective: Set up virtual machines and application containers to run applications for different operating systems on a single host.

learningOutcomes.name: Cloud Computing
learningOutcomes.objective: Provision a simple web server on AWS.  Gain experience with AWS services.

learningOutcomes.name: Deployment
learningOutcomes.objective: Use a tool to build a simple deployment pipeline.

learningOutcomes.name: Dependency Injection
learningOutcomes.objective: Understand the benefits of dependency injection.

learningOutcomes.name: Object-relational Mapping
learningOutcomes.objective: Gain experience with an object-relational mapping framework.

nonEnforcedPrerequisites: With instructor consent, may be taken concurrently with C S 202 and 203.

description: How a computer works to execute sequential code: low level data representation and abstraction, the relationship between C and assembly, computer architecture and pipelining, the memory hierarchy, dynamic memory allocation, and linking.\n
name: Computer Systems

learningOutcomes.name: Binary Computations
learningOutcomes.objective: Ability to perform simple computations in binary.

learningOutcomes.name: C Programming
learningOutcomes.objective: Ability to program in C.

learningOutcomes.name: Assembly Programming
learningOutcomes.objective: Ability to program in assembly.

learningOutcomes.name: Translating C code to Assembly
learningOutcomes.objective: Ability to describe how a compiler translates C code to assembly.

learningOutcomes.name: Computer Operation
learningOutcomes.objective: Ability to describe the operation of a computer at the micro-architectural level

learningOutcomes.name: Boolean Logic
learningOutcomes.objective: Perform computations using Boolean logic

learningOutcomes.name: Translate Boolean
learningOutcomes.objective: Translate Boolean logic to transistor circuitry

learningOutcomes.name: Circuitry
learningOutcomes.objective: Use combinational and sequential circuitry to implement an instruction set architecture

learningOutcomes.name: Computer Architecture
learningOutcomes.objective: Ability to describe the high level organization and operation of a computer, e.g. the von Neumann model

nonEnforcedPrerequisites: or instructor's consent.

description: Fundamental data structures and algorithms of computer science; basic algorithm analysis; recursion; sorting and searching; lists, stacks, queues, trees, hashing; object-oriented data abstraction.
name: Data Structures

learningOutcomes.name: Data Computing Fundamentals
learningOutcomes.objective: Use the fundamental data types of computing (lists, stacks, queues, priority queues, sets, maps, trees, etc.).

learningOutcomes.name: Implementing Fundamental Data Types
learningOutcomes.objective: Understand the major techniques for implementing the fundamental data types (linked lists, binary search trees, hashing, heaps, etc.) and implement several of them.

learningOutcomes.name: Select Data Structures
learningOutcomes.objective: Properly use and select data structures from language-provided data-structure libraries.

learningOutcomes.name: Analysis
learningOutcomes.objective: Apply basic algorithm analysis.

learningOutcomes.name: Recursion
learningOutcomes.objective: Understand how recursion works and write programs using recursion to solve problems.

learningOutcomes.name: Usage of Algorithms
learningOutcomes.objective: Make informed decisions about which sorting and searching algorithms to use in specific circumstances.

learningOutcomes.name: Program Writing
learningOutcomes.objective: Write programs that require ~500 lines of code.

description: Introduction to grammars and parsing; predicate and propositional logic; proof techniques; sets, functions, relations, relational data model; graphs and graph algorithms.
name: Discrete Structure

learningOutcomes.name: Write Code From Diverse Program Components
learningOutcomes.objective: Demonstrate ability to build large programs by writing and integrating code from a diverse spectrum of program components.

learningOutcomes.name: Use Mathematical Structures to Solve Programming Problems
learningOutcomes.objective: Understand and be conversant with basic discrete mathematical structures (finite state machines, regular expressions, grammars, propositional calculus, proof techniques, predicate calculus, sets, relations, functions, graphs).Write complex programs by using mathematical concepts as the basis for solving programming problems (finite state machines for lexical analysis; grammars for parsing; propositional and predicate calculus for logic programming; sets and algebras for relational databases; algebras, graphs, and topological sorting for optimizing datalog query processing).Incrementally build sophisticated programs by a systematic design process based on discrete mathematics.Design a solution for a programming problem and justify the design as one that is maintainable and extendable by other programmers who understand and are conversant with discrete mathematical structures.

description: Advanced software development with an object-oriented focus. Design, implementation, and testing of medium-sized programs including a server program.
name: Adv Software Construction

learningOutcomes.name: Construction
learningOutcomes.objective: Learn to construct a medium-scale server program with data persistence in a principled way by applying relevant engineering techniques such as up-front design, quality code construction, unit testing, assertions, and error handling.

learningOutcomes.name: Design
learningOutcomes.objective: Learn and apply basic software design principles such as single responsibility, low coupling, avoidance of code duplication and information/data hiding to create modular code.

learningOutcomes.name: Databases
learningOutcomes.objective: Learn and apply the basics of relational database design, modeling and programmatic access.

learningOutcomes.name: Security
learningOutcomes.objective: Learn and apply basic security principles and concepts.

learningOutcomes.name: Testing
learningOutcomes.objective: Learn to validate a program’s behavior against its specification using testing practices.

learningOutcomes.name: Tools
learningOutcomes.objective: Use modern software tools including integrated development environments, testing frameworks, debuggers, version control, and documentation processing tools.

nonEnforcedPrerequisites: or instructor's consent.

description: Finite state automata, regular languages, lexical analysis; push-down automata, context-free languages, parsing; Turing machines and unrestricted grammars; computability complexity, NP-completeness.
name: Intro to Computational Theory

learningOutcomes.name: Understand Paradigms
learningOutcomes.objective: Understand the difference between and limitations of paradigms.

learningOutcomes.name: Decidable and Tractable
learningOutcomes.objective: Understand the difference between computable (decidable) and practically computable (tractable).

learningOutcomes.name: Categorize Problems
learningOutcomes.objective: Categorize problems into one of the existing paradigms.

learningOutcomes.name: Solutions to Problems
learningOutcomes.objective: Design and justify solutions to problems of decidability and tractability.

learningOutcomes.name: Understand Computing Paradigms
learningOutcomes.objective: Understand the three computing paradigms (DFAs, PDA, Turing Machine) and their language-based equivalents (regular languages,context-free languages, computable algorithms).

nonEnforcedPrerequisites: C S 236 or concurrent enrollment.

description: Design user experiences with technology that make a meaningful difference in people’s lives. Methods to establish user needs, derive designs, assess tradeoffs, and report results. Develop and iterate prototypes with feedback from representative users.
name: Introduction to HCI

learningOutcomes.name: Meet user needs
learningOutcomes.objective: Analyze users and their environments for the purpose of designing to meet their needs.

learningOutcomes.name: Create human-centered designs
learningOutcomes.objective: Apply an iterative human-centered design cycle to create, develop, and evaluate technology user experiences.

learningOutcomes.name: Analyze user interfaces
learningOutcomes.objective: Describe and analyze user interfaces for best-practice user interface approaches, including diverse form factors and accessibility issues.

learningOutcomes.name: Document user experiences
learningOutcomes.objective: Present and document user experience findings and the results of user experience projects and analysis using technical writing and presentation standards.

description: Introduction to building and deploying full stack web applications using core technologies, frameworks, protocols, and development tools.
name: Web Programming

learningOutcomes.name: Web Pages
learningOutcomes.objective: Create interactive web applications using HTML, CSS, and JavaScript.

learningOutcomes.name: Web Frameworks
learningOutcomes.objective: Modularize, build, and package an application using a web framework.

learningOutcomes.name: Web Services
learningOutcomes.objective: Create a backend service using DNS, HTTPS, WebSocket, service endpoints, authentication, and data persistence.

learningOutcomes.name: Infrastructure
learningOutcomes.objective: Deploy applications and manage code.

learningOutcomes.name: Security and Design
learningOutcomes.objective: Appreciate production web application security and design practices.

description: Understand the fundamental models of machine learning, such as neural networks, decision trees, data mining, clustering, Bayesian learning, ensembles, reinforcement learning, and deep learning. Work with data and machine learning tools in real world applications.
name: Intro to Machine Learning

learningOutcomes.name: Machine Learning Knowledge
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will be able to understand and apply the basic theory, models, and concepts of machine learning and be prepared for subsequent machine learning courses.
Students will be able to recognize when machine learning approaches are applicable.
learningOutcomes.name: Recognize
Execute
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will be able to use machine learning approaches in real world applications.

description: Career advising for students in computer science. Advice on resumes, applications, and interviews for internships, full-time jobs, and graduate school. Opportunities to network with other students and with employers.
name: Careers in CS

learningOutcomes.name: Employment Plan
learningOutcomes.objective: Make a detailed and personalized plan for obtaining an internship and full-time employment

learningOutcomes.name: Professional Connections
learningOutcomes.objective: Make connections with students pursuing similar career paths and with potential employers.

learningOutcomes.name: Occupational roles
learningOutcomes.objective: Identify the duties and skills needed for a variety of roles in the workplace.

nonEnforcedPrerequisites: Recommend during freshman year or second semester after transferring to BYU

description: Undergraduate-level topics as announced.
name: Topics in Computer Science

learningOutcomes.name: Data gathering
learningOutcomes.objective: Because 301R is an experiment course, data on how well the course accomplished the outcomes will be gathered.  This will usually be in the form of surveys, exam scores, and project scores.

learningOutcomes.name: Experimental course
learningOutcomes.objective: A 301R course is used by a professor who is teaching an experimental course.  Learning outcomes will vary for the course, but these outcomes are evaluated during the vetting process (through the department undergraduate curriculum committee) before the professor is allowed to teach the course.  At this level, typical learning outcomes involve computing practice, critical thinking, and more advanced theory.

nonEnforcedPrerequisites: Instructor's consent

description: A study of the design and analysis of algorithms as solutions to problems, including dynamic programming, linear programming, greedy algorithms, divide-and-conquer algorithms, graph algorithms, and intelligent search algorithms.
name: Algorithm Design & Analysis

learningOutcomes.name: Efficiency
learningOutcomes.objective: The student can make the distinction between problems and their algorithmic solutions. Moreover, the student can distinguish between efficient and inefficient solutions and can relate these distinctions to the complexity classes of problems, namely P, NP, and NP-Complete learned earlier in the curriculum (CS 252).

learningOutcomes.name: Fundamental Computer Algorithms
learningOutcomes.objective: The student understands fundamental computer algorithms that can be organized in the following algorithmic paradigms: dynamic programming, linear programming, greedy algorithms, divide-and-conquer algorithms, graph algorithms, intelligent search algorithms, and --to a lesser degree--randomized algorithms. As an algorithmic problem solver, the student can formulate novel or unfamiliar problems in mathematical terms so as to elucidate a given problem's relation to known problems, choose a paradigm for solving the problem, and design an algorithm to solve the problem.

learningOutcomes.name: Correctness
learningOutcomes.objective: The student can prove the correctness of a subset of the algorithms considered in the course.

learningOutcomes.name: Analysis
learningOutcomes.objective: The student can analyze algorithms belonging to those algorithmic paradigms for their asymptotic worst-case behavior in terms of time and space. Furthermore, the student can analyze algorithms empirically (under simplifying assumptions) and understands the relationship of empirical analysis to average-case behavior.

learningOutcomes.name: Implementation
learningOutcomes.objective: The student can independently implement selected algorithms in the context of motivating applications using Python.

description: Systems programming principles and concepts, including Linux systems programming, multiprocessing, concurrency, exceptional control flow, caching, sockets, protocols, and non-blocking I/O.
name: Systems Programming

learningOutcomes.name: Demonstrate Linux Systems Programming
learningOutcomes.objective: Use Linux APIs and command line

learningOutcomes.name: Demonstrate multiprocessing, concurrency and exceptional control flow
learningOutcomes.objective: Write programs that use concurrency

learningOutcomes.name: Analyze caching, sockets and non-blocking I/O
learningOutcomes.objective: Write programs and analyze their performance

description: Comprehensive production software testing, deployment, and management strategies, focusing on automation, security, quality assurance, continuous integration/deployment, scalability, and resilience.
name: QA & DevOps

learningOutcomes.name: Quality
learningOutcomes.objective: Implement comprehensive automated testing strategies, including unit, UI, E2E, performance, and load testing.

learningOutcomes.name: Deployment
learningOutcomes.objective: Deploy various automated CI/CD pipeline strategies to reliably deliver software that is resilient, scalable, and secure.

learningOutcomes.name: Management
learningOutcomes.objective: Monitor, detect anomalies, alter, and automatically correct system behavior.

learningOutcomes.name: Curious
learningOutcomes.objective: Characterize and address gaps in understanding related to DevOps techniques and principles.

learningOutcomes.name: Creative
learningOutcomes.objective: Discuss and generate alternatives DevOps designs.

learningOutcomes.name: Collaborative
learningOutcomes.objective: Work as a team to discover DevOps design weaknesses.

learningOutcomes.name: Christlike
learningOutcomes.objective: Strive for divine inspiration for, and ability to apply capabilities to, celestial pursuits.

description: Principles and concepts characterizing high-level computer programming languages, process and data abstration, encapsulation, inheritance, functional programming, logic programming, scanners, and parsers.
name: Concepts of Programng Lang

learningOutcomes.name: Program Language Flexibility
learningOutcomes.objective: Be able to write programs using non-imperative language paradigms.

learningOutcomes.name: Programming Language Familiarity
learningOutcomes.objective: Learn the vocabulary of programming language design, syntax, and semantics

description: Use design, development, testing and refactoring techniques to build and evolve reliable, maintainable and scalable software systems. Covers a wide range of design patterns and principles. Also introduces students to software architecture and architectural patterns.
name: Software Design

learningOutcomes.name: Design Judgement
learningOutcomes.objective: Know when and how to apply various design patterns.

learningOutcomes.name: Software Design Principles
learningOutcomes.objective: Understand the principles of effective software design.

learningOutcomes.name: Document and Communicate Designs
learningOutcomes.objective: Learn to effectively document and communicate software designs.

learningOutcomes.name: Cloud Computing Technologies
learningOutcomes.objective: Gain experience implementing software designs using cloud computing technologies.

description: Principles and concepts of operating systems design and the implementation of an operating system.
name: Operating Systems Design

learningOutcomes.name: Operating System Basics
learningOutcomes.objective: Describe the basic components of an operating system and their role in implementations for general purpose, real-time, and embedded applications.

learningOutcomes.name: Basic Concepts
learningOutcomes.objective: Define the concepts of processes, threads, asynchronous signals and competitive system resource allocation.

learningOutcomes.name: Shells
learningOutcomes.objective: Show how a shell works.

learningOutcomes.name: Scheduling Algorithms for Multi-Tasking
learningOutcomes.objective: Explain what multi-tasking is and outline standard scheduling algorithms for multi-tasking.

learningOutcomes.name: Mutual Exclusion Principles
learningOutcomes.objective: Discuss mutual exclusion principles and their use in concurrent programming, including semaphore construction and resource allocation.

learningOutcomes.name: System Memory Management
learningOutcomes.objective: Give an overview of system memory management.

learningOutcomes.name: Implementing File Systems
learningOutcomes.objective: Explain how file systems are implemented.

learningOutcomes.name: Competing Operating Systems
learningOutcomes.objective: Discuss the features and strengths of various contemporary operating systems.

learningOutcomes.name: Implement an Operating System
learningOutcomes.objective: Implement a functional, pre-emptive, multi-tasking operating system written in C, including a shell, scheduler, file manager, memory manager, and synchronization components.

description: Introduces basic concepts of computer graphics and image processing. Includes characteristics of physical cameras and displays; color models; basic image processing algorithms: 2D and 3D homogeneous coordinate transformations; fundamentals of 3D rendering geometry; lighting and shading: image warping and texture mapping; and frequency-domain processing.
name: Graphics and Image Processing

learningOutcomes.name: Mathematics and Geometry
learningOutcomes.objective:
Use and implement the fundamental mathematical concepts underlying these areas, including

Points, vectors, and matrices
Other basic principles of linear algebra
Geometric transformations as matrices
Methods for working with numeric data

learningOutcomes.name: Graphical User Interfaces
learningOutcomes.objective:
Use and implement concepts of current graphical user interfaces (which you should have seen before), including

Model-view-controller architecture
Event handling
Screen management

learningOutcomes.name: 2D Drawing, Viewing, and Selection
learningOutcomes.objective:
Use and implement the following concepts for 2D drawing, viewing, and selection:

Geometry of simple shapes
2D Transformations
Transformation composition

learningOutcomes.name: 3D Rendering Geometry
learningOutcomes.objective:
Understand and implement the fundamental geometry involved in 3-D perspective rendering, including

Use rendering libraries such as OpenGL to do simple rendering
Implement the geometric transformations used in 3D rendering
Identify basic techniques for shading and their advantages and limitations

learningOutcomes.name: Basic Image Processing
learningOutcomes.objective:
Understand and implement fundamental image processing operations, including 

Point operations (brightness, contrast, etc.)
Image-Image operations (differencing, alpha blending, etc.)
Neighborhood operations (noise removal, edge detection, etc.)

learningOutcomes.name: Geometric Operations on Images
learningOutcomes.objective: Understand and implement image warping using a backwards-mapping approach

learningOutcomes.name: Color
learningOutcomes.objective: Understandand use the language and principles of common color models

description: This class combines designing the user experience with implementing the technology. Students learn website design, information architecture, and how to design for the broader ecosystem of use. Finally, students will learn principles specifically relevant to website design and information architecture. Web design is one of the most common UX jobs and so this makes their skills highly marketable.
long_name: Advanced Techniques in Human Computer Interaction
name: Advanced Techniques in HCI

learningOutcomes.name: Analyze the Context of a Design Problem
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will learn how to analyze secondary data related to their design problem in order to understand the context in which people are using a given technology. Namely, this class goes beyond just interviewing users and to analyzing multiple sources of data that helps them understand the context in which the users are using the technology. This could include analyzing bug report, comments on social media, Q&A forums, other documentation about the topic, interview transcripts from multiple sets of stakeholders (e.g., users v. non users).

learningOutcomes.name: Design the Different Stakeholders.
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will be able to apply methods such as Personas to represent multiple stakeholders who are affected by the technology. This will allow them to analyze the characteristics of and segment the target population.

learningOutcomes.name: Apply Advanced Design Principles
learningOutcomes.objective: Understand and apply design patterns and theories of information to the design of an online systerm.

learningOutcomes.name: Implement Functional Prototype
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will be able to specify and implement/create a functional prototype that improves on the user experience of the design problem.

learningOutcomes.name: Evaluate Design Improvement
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will be able to compare different designs to determine which has a better user experience using techniques such as A/B testing. This could be comparing the existing website that they have been analyzing, with a newly proposed/implemented website design for the same organization.

description: Strengthen problem-solving skills through targeted practice to prepare for technical/coding interviews (a key challenge when job interviewing). Building on techniques from CS 312, learn to collaborate and quickly identify and apply appropriate strategies to problems.
name: Collaborative Probl Solving

learningOutcomes.name: Demonstrate problem solving
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will be able to solve problems quickly to enable them to be competitive in technical lnterviews

learningOutcomes.name: Build problem-solving strategies
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will build on the algorithms and problem-solving strategies that they were taught and had limited practice with in CS 312. learning primarily through targeted practice.

nonEnforcedPrerequisites: or instructor consent

description: Undergraduate level subjects as announced before each semester.
name: Topics in Computer Science

learningOutcomes.name: Special Topics
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will learn about a topic in Computer Science not covered in the traditional courses.

nonEnforcedPrerequisites: Instructor's consent

description: Societal impact of computer technology, the computer scientist's place in society, ethical issues.  Reading, discussion, and writing seminar.
name: Ethics & Computers in Society

learningOutcomes.name: Ethics
learningOutcomes.objective: Analyze, write about, and discuss issues and ethical problems related to computing and the application of evolving technologies in society.

learningOutcomes.name: History of Computing
learningOutcomes.objective: Appreciate the history of computing as a means for students to sharpen their sense of their own future.

learningOutcomes.name: Continuing Education
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will understand the need for continuing education in their careers.

learningOutcomes.name: Presenting Ideas
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will be able to effectively present their ideas.

description: Entrepreneurship, idea/opportunity generation, strategic planning, legal organization, product development, marketing/sales, customer support, fund raising, and effective management.
long_name: Creating and Managing a Software Business
name: Software Business

learningOutcomes.name: Business Plan
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will write a business plan for a company they are proposing.

description: Optimization, problem formulation, and solution algorithms, including simplex and interior point methods.  Applications from control, data mining, finance, game theory, learning, network flow, operations research, and statistical estimation.
name: Linear Prog/Convx Optimization

learningOutcomes.name: Mathematical Foundations
learningOutcomes.objective: Develop a fluency in the mathematical foundations needed to pose optimization problems, including an appreciation for the role of convexity in characterizing solvable problems.

learningOutcomes.name: Simplex Method
learningOutcomes.objective: Develop a fluency with the Simplex Method as a solution technique to Linear Programming problems. Understand how it exploits the linear nature of the problem to yield good average-case performance while failing to be efficient in the worst-case.

learningOutcomes.name: Sensitivity Analysis
learningOutcomes.objective: Be able to characterize how to perturb the data of an existing problem so that its solution remains optimal for the new, perturbed problem.

learningOutcomes.name: Applications
learningOutcomes.objective: Explore the role of Linear and Convex Programming in a variety of applications, including 1) Finance, 2) Game Theory, 3) Regression, and 4) Computer Networking.

learningOutcomes.name: Interior Point Methods
learningOutcomes.objective: Develop a fluency with interior point methods for solving Linear Programming problems and understand how these solutions may be extended to solve nonlinear, convex optimization problems.

learningOutcomes.name: Duality Theory
learningOutcomes.objective: Understand the meaning of weak and strong duality and their role in the design and verification of algorithmic solutions to optimization problems.

nonEnforcedPrerequisites: or instructor's consent.

description: Advanced Algorithms and Problem Solving topics including combinatorics, prime number theory, network flow and matching, computational geometry, randomized algorithms, advanced dynamic programming, algorithms and data structures for strings, trees, graphs and sequences.
name: Advanced Algorithms

learningOutcomes.objective: Develop understanding and familiarity with a wide range of advanced algorithms, data structures and problem-solving paradigms and techniques.
learningOutcomes.name: Knowledge of Advanced Algorithms

learningOutcomes.objective: Apply existing algorithms and paradigms to solve computational problems.  Moreover, students will develop the ability to adapt, extend and combine techniques for solving more novel problems.
learningOutcomes.name: Algorithm Application and Design

learningOutcomes.objective: Develop ability to see a posed problem and consider different approaches to solve it, weigh the feasibility of each and the tradeoffs between them, and ultimately select a promising paradigm to pursue.
learningOutcomes.name: Problem Characterization/Method Selection

learningOutcomes.objective: Develop the ability to: (1) create your own implementation of a known algorithm; and, (2) use either your implementation or an existing one to successfully solve posed problems.
learningOutcomes.name: Algorithm Implementation and Application

description: Analysis, design, implementation, and testing of significant software systems.
name: Software Engineering

learningOutcomes.name: Group Dynamics
learningOutcomes.objective: Demonstrate the ability to work in a group on a significant project

learningOutcomes.name: Software Engineering Fundamentals
learningOutcomes.objective: Demonstrate practices that result in quality software

learningOutcomes.name: Software Ethics
learningOutcomes.objective: Demonstrate an understanding of how ethics impact software development

description:
Introduction to mathematical formalization and techniques to rigorously establish properties of data structures, functions, and whole programs, including imperative features. Students use a proof assistant embedding several languages including an advanced functional
language.
name: Formal Verification

learningOutcomes.objective: Compare and contrast the purely functional, logical, and embedded logic methods of definition and articulate the consequences of a particular method on a concept.
learningOutcomes.name: Formalism Design

learningOutcomes.objective: State and prove essential algebraic properties of mathematical operations such as commutativity, associativity, and idempotency.
learningOutcomes.name: Algebraic Properties

learningOutcomes.objective: Recognize, produce, and apply metatheoretical properties such as soundness, completeness, and congruence.
learningOutcomes.name: Theory Design

learningOutcomes.objective: Express semantics in operational, denotational, and axiomatic formulations and articulate the relative advantages of each.
learningOutcomes.name: Semantics Design

learningOutcomes.objective: Conceive of and express formal correctness properties of systems without a reference implementation.
learningOutcomes.name: Verification Mindset

learningOutcomes.objective: Express and prove properties about programs using the most advanced extant type systems.
learningOutcomes.name: Dependently-Typed Programming

description: Formal description of algorithmic languages and techniques used in their compilation:  semantics, ambiguities, procedures, replication, iteration, recursion.
name: Algorithmic Lang & Compilers

learningOutcomes.name: Write a compiler
learningOutcomes.objective: Implement a fully functional compiler for a subset of the Java language that targets an embedded microprocess.

learningOutcomes.name: Use interesting data types and algorithms in a large program
learningOutcomes.objective: Apply patterns and common data structures to compiler constructrion including tree traversal, graph algorithms, and proof systems.

learningOutcomes.name: Apply techniques from compiler construction to other problem
learningOutcomes.objective: Students are able to synthesis algorithms and techniques from compiler constructor to other problem domains.

learningOutcomes.name: Mental model of compilation
learningOutcomes.objective: Students have a sound mental model of how an abstract high level language is systematically transformed into a low-level machine langauge or byte code. Students are able to use that understanding to write better application code.

description: Introduction to fundamental concepts and algorithms of computer vision, including feature extraction, detection, segmentation, registration, recognition, motion, 3D vision, and image understanding. Applies techniques from image processing, geometry, Bayesian methods, optimization, and machine learning to computer vision problems.
name: Computer Vision

learningOutcomes.name: Introduction to Digital Signal and Image Processing
learningOutcomes.objective:
Understand and apply the following:

Sampling and quantization of image information
Camera properties and the acquisition of images
Mathematics of image-space transformations
Fourier transforms and filtering

description: Database models:  relational, deductive, object-oriented.  Integrity constraints, query languages, database design.
name: Database Modeling Concepts

learningOutcomes.name: Query Languages
learningOutcomes.objective: Be able to use a variety of commercial query languages (SQL, XQuery, SPARQL), both stand-alone and embeded in high-level programming languages. Know how relational algebra and relational calculus provide a basis for commercial query languages.

learningOutcomes.name: Query Optimization
learningOutcomes.objective: Understand performance issues and optimization strategies. This includes query rewriting, secondary storage characteristics, and access strategies.

learningOutcomes.name: Database Design
learningOutcomes.objective: Be able to design and develop relational database applications. This includes conceptual modeling and normalization theory.

learningOutcomes.name: Current Challenges
learningOutcomes.objective: Be familiar with some of the current challenges facing database professionals.

description: Concepts and terminology of information retrieval (IR) systems.  Design methodologies and issues.  Fundamental IR models examined:  Boolean, Vector Space, Probabilistic models, and evaluation strategies.
name: Fund of Information Retrieval

learningOutcomes.name: Understand and evaluate fundamental IR models
learningOutcomes.objective:
Boolean
Vector Space
Probabilistic

learningOutcomes.name: Query Construction
learningOutcomes.objective: Represent user's information needs, refine user's queries, and construct query results using snippets and categories

learningOutcomes.name: Query Processing
learningOutcomes.objective: Extract, parse, index, and classify source information for query processing

learningOutcomes.name: Machine Learning
learningOutcomes.objective: Categorize, cluster, and filter query results using various supervised and unsupervised learning strategies

learningOutcomes.name: Analysis
learningOutcomes.objective: Evaluate the effectiveness, efficiency, and cost of performing searches using search engines

description: Interactive computer graphics systems programming and architecture.
name: Computer Graphics

learningOutcomes.name: Understanding fundamental principles of computer graphics
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will be proficient in basic computer graphics algorithms such as modeling, trnasformations and rendering.Students will design and code solutions to several programming problems in graphics using algorithms and data structures.In addition, sutudents will use these techniques to program a large semester project.

description: Iterative user experience design for mobile and ubiquitous computing with an emphasis on conceptualization and prototyping in specific contexts. Complete an open-ended project from initial design through functional prototype, with design and critique sessions.
name: Mobile and Ubiquitous HCI

learningOutcomes.name: Needs analysis
learningOutcomes.objective: Characterize user needs in a specific context using inductive research methods

learningOutcomes.name: Mobile sensors
learningOutcomes.objective: Implement mobile phone applications that use sensors found in a mobile phone

learningOutcomes.name: Screenless applications
learningOutcomes.objective: Implement screenless applications using small portable computers

learningOutcomes.name: Theory
learningOutcomes.objective: Discuss important issues in mobile and ubiquitous computing in the context of relevant theories.

learningOutcomes.name: Evaluation of prototypes
learningOutcomes.objective: Characterize strengths and weaknesses of an interactive system based on user-centric evaluation.

description: Introduction to data communications and computer networking.  Communications fundamentals, computer networks, software, architecture, telecommunications, regulation, standards.
name: Comp Comms & Networking

learningOutcomes.name: Internet Architecture
learningOutcomes.objective: Understand the principles of the Internet architecture

learningOutcomes.name: Internet Design
learningOutcomes.objective: Understand how the Internet works, from the transport layer down to the physical layer

learningOutcomes.name: Internet Implementation
learningOutcomes.objective: Gain hands-on experience with implementing and simulating transport, routing, and MAC protocols, leading to a deeper understanding of these critical Internet components

learningOutcomes.name: Internet Research
learningOutcomes.objective: Be capable of reading and understanding research papers in the area of computer networking

learningOutcomes.name: Scholarly Communication
learningOutcomes.objective: Demonstrate the ability to effectively conduct, describe and report on an experimental research project in the area of computer networking

description: Principles and concepts of designing and building distributed systems.  Introduction to architectures for distributed computation.  Reliability, availability, and scalability of large applications.  Cloud computing and APIs.
name: Distributed System Design
note: Students are allowed 1 repeat of each C S undergraduate course (all 100-, 200-, 300- or 400-level courses). This includes all students who received any grade including those who withdraw (receive a "W" grade) from a C S course. Students must wait 1 semester/term before being allowed to take a course they have failed twice. Petitions for exceptions to the policy can be completed at cs.byu.edu/undergraduate-handbook/retake-policy-cs-courses/.

learningOutcomes.name: Computational Practice
learningOutcomes.objective:
Students can implement programming projects that display knowledge of a variety of distributed system architectural styles. Some of these assignments represent significant programming projects with wide leeway in design and implementation choices.
Students will analyze problems, determine solutions within an assigned architectural style, and successfully implement those solutions.
Students will design and implement projects both individually and as part of a team.
Students will use cloud-based systems to run and implement assignments
Students will manage a cloud-based Web server and properly configure it.

learningOutcomes.name: Computational Theory
learningOutcomes.objective:
Students will understand the proper use of distributed and decentralized architectures and algorithms including

RESTful APIs
Hierarchical vs heterarchical system architectures
MapReduce
Distributed Hash Tables
Event-driven system
Peer-to-peer architectures including Paxos, gossip protocols, and blockchain

Students will understand theoretical concepts and limitations of distributed systems including

network practicalities such as latency, bandwidth, topology, cost, heterogeneity, security
CAP theorem
distributed transactions
serialization
identity and naming
cryptography
simultaneity

learningOutcomes.name: Critical Thinking and Communication
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will interact with peers in meaningful discussion, lead discussions in peer groups, prepare written reports, and make oral presentations.

learningOutcomes.name: Ethics and Computing
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will be presented with societal outcomes of technological choices in distributed and decentralized systems, analyze those outcomes, explore possible alternatives from different choices, and present their findings in small groups.

nonEnforcedPrerequisites: or equivalent experience.

description: Introduction to computer security fundamentals: confidentiality, integrity, authentication, and access control. Secret key and public key cryptography, network security protocols, viruses, and fire walls.
name: Computer Security

learningOutcomes.name: Build a system
learningOutcomes.objective: Implement a cryptographic algorithm from a standards specification.

learningOutcomes.name: Break and fix a system
learningOutcomes.objective: Demonstrate how attackers compromise real-world systems, and then show how to prevent these attacks.

nonEnforcedPrerequisites: or concurrent enrollment.

description: Technical underpinnings of blockchain-based systems, including cryptocurrency, smart contracts, decentralized finance (De-Fi), and Web3. Explores which problems are suitable for a blockchain-based solution and discusses arguments in favor and against blockchain systems.
name: Blockchain Technologies

learningOutcomes.name: Implementation
learningOutcomes.objective: Design and implement a simple blockchain, a Merkle tree, and a proof-of-work algorithm.

learningOutcomes.name: Problem Fit
learningOutcomes.objective: Given a problem, articulate why it may or may not be a good fit for a blockchain.

learningOutcomes.name: Smart Contract Security
learningOutcomes.objective: Understand smart contract security by breaking and fixing Solidity smart contracts

learningOutcomes.name: Trade-offs
learningOutcomes.objective: Present arguments for and against cryptocurrency systems. Title

description: Introduction to core areas of artifical intelligence; intelligent agents, problem solving and search, knowledge-based systems and inference, planning, uncertainty, learning, and perception.
name: Intro Artificial Intelligence

learningOutcomes.name: Recognize problems that can use AI methods
learningOutcomes.objective: from business, medicine, robotics, gaming, and machine learning

learningOutcomes.name: Identify the component elements of the problem
learningOutcomes.objective:
Does it require basic control?
Does it involve uncertain reasoning?
Does it have a simple goal, sophisticated utility, or multiple attributes?
Does it require sequential choice or planning?
How may decision makers are involved?

learningOutcomes.name: Formalize the problem in a way that is amenable to a solutio
learningOutcomes.objective:
What is the internal representation?
What performance criteria are relevant?
What is the nature of the environment?
What are the actuators?
What are the sensors?
What are the agent's utilities?
How is uncertainty represented?

learningOutcomes.name: Be able to analyze, implement, and experiment with several A
learningOutcomes.objective:
Uninformed, informed, constraint-satisfaction, hill-climbing, and stochastic (e.g., genetic algorithms) search
Markov provesses, Bayes rule, Bayes nets, Hidden Markov Models, Grid Filters, and Kalman Filters
Expected utility theory
Multi-attribute utility theory
Sequential choice under uncertainty: value and policy iteration
Minimax solutions from game theory: alpha-beta pruning

learningOutcomes.name: Analyze and communicate solution quality
learningOutcomes.objective:
Determine whether your solution is correct
Express the quality of your solution
Value the need to communicate your solution to others

description: Methods and development platforms for Voice User Interfaces. Principles of effective design; differences from visual or menu-based interfaces’ mechanics of automatic speech recognition, intent detection, slot filling, dialog state tracking, text generation, and knowledge representation.
name: Voice Interfaces

learningOutcomes.name: Develop a voice interface for a program
learningOutcomes.objective: Methods and development platforms for Voice User Interfaces. Principles of effective design; differences from visual or menu-based interfaces' mechanics of automatic speech recognition, intent detection, slot filling, dialog state tracking, text generation, and knowledge representation.

recommended: Students should be proficient in basic coding skills and familiar with Python

description: Machine learning models and other mechanisms allowing computers to learn and find knowledge from data.
name: Intro to Machine Learning

learningOutcomes.name: Recognize
learningOutcomes.objective: You will be able to recognize when machine learning and data mining tools are applicable.

learningOutcomes.name: Execute
learningOutcomes.objective: You will be able to plan and execute successful machine learning and data mining projects, including selecting an adequate process for your specific task and avoiding the main machine learning pitfalls.

learningOutcomes.name: Use Effective Machine Learning Techniques
learningOutcomes.objective: You will learn the basic theory and models used in machine learning

description: Understand the fundamental models of machine learning, such as neural networks, decision trees, data mining, clustering, Bayesian learning, ensembles, reinforcement learning, and deep learning. Work with data and machine learning tools in real world applications.
name: Advanced Machine Learning

learningOutcomes.name: Machine Learning Expertise
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will be able to implement machine learning models and learning algorithms.

learningOutcomes.name: Mathematical and Statistical Expertise
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will be able to create new machine learning models using tools from math and stats.
Students will be able to read academic literature and incorporate ideas into their own toolbox.
learningOutcomes.name: Lifelong learning

description: Understand theory and practice of deep learning, drawing material from machine vision, machine translation, dynamical systems, audio processing, neural computing and human perception. Learn supporting mathematical concepts, including linear algebra, stochastic optimization, and hardware acceleration.
name: Deep Learning

learningOutcomes.name: Analyze Deep Learning
learningOutcomes.objective: Theory and practice of modern deep learning and associated software frameworks. A broad look at the field, drawing on material from machine vision, machine translation, dynamical systems, audio processing, neural computing and human perception. Supporting mathematical concepts are also covered, including linear algebra, stochastic optimization, and hardware acceleration.

description: Supervised, full-day, four week experience to develop and demonstrate competence in teaching minor area course content in the secondary classroom.
name: Sec Minor Student Teaching
nonEnforcedPrerequisites: Sc Ed 477R or minor area equivalent; admittance to teaching area; FBI fingerprint background clearance.

description: Evolution of machine translation technologies and algorithms, with a foundation in basic algorithms, human-machine interaction, automatic adaptation, statistical and neural models, multilingual models, multimodal models, quality evaluation and estimation, and speech-to-speech translation.
name: Intro to Machine Translation

learningOutcomes.name: MT Technology Evolution
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will understand how the challenges of producing quality translations have been addressed by past and present technologies

learningOutcomes.name: Building blocks of MT Technology
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will be able to prepare data to be used to train MT systems, apply and interpret quality metrics to MT output, and implement basic MT-related algorithms

learningOutcomes.name: MT Tools and Platforms
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will be able to identify and use available platforms and tools to create MT systems for selected languages

learningOutcomes.name: MT Applications
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will be able to create and incorporate MT systems and/or MT-related functionality in a selected scenario or application

learningOutcomes.name: Advanced MT algorithms
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will become familiar with and be able to implement and use basic versions of certain more advanced MT algorithms used in current MT research

nonEnforcedPrerequisites: Reading ability in a language other than English.
recommended: Python proficiency, CS 474 or CS 472 or Ling 581 or similar exposure to MT or NLP technologies.

description: Culminating experience based on skills learned in advanced technical courses. Students work in teams to plan, design, implement, test, and demonstrate a major project.\n
name: Soft Eng Capstone 1

learningOutcomes.name: Students will design and implement software
learningOutcomes.objective: Culminating experience based on skills learned in advanced technical courses. Students work in teams to plan, design, implement, test, and demonstrate a major project.

nonEnforcedPrerequisites: Minimum 3.0 CS GPA or instructor's consent.

description: Culminating experience based on skills learned in advanced technical courses. Students work in teams to plan, design, implement, test, and demonstrate a major project.
name: Soft Eng Capstone 2

learningOutcomes.name: Students will design and implement software
learningOutcomes.objective: Culminating experience based on skills learned in advanced technical courses. Students work in teams to plan, design, implement, test, and demonstrate a major project.

nonEnforcedPrerequisites: Minimum 3.0 CS GPA or instructor's consent.

description: Culminating experience based on skills learned in advanced technical courses. Students work in teams to plan, design, implement, test, and demonstrate a major project.
name: Data Science Capstone 1

learningOutcomes.name: Students will design and implement a data science solution
learningOutcomes.objective: Culminating experience based on skills learned in advanced technical courses. Students work in teams to plan, design, implement, test, and demonstrate a major project.

nonEnforcedPrerequisites: Minimum 3.0 CS GPA or instructor's consent.

description: Culminating experience based on skills learned in advanced technical courses. Students work in teams to plan, design, implement, test, and demonstrate a major project.
name: Data Science Capstone 2

learningOutcomes.name: Students will design and implement a data science solution
learningOutcomes.objective: Culminating experience based on skills learned in advanced technical courses. Students work in teams to plan, design, implement, test, and demonstrate a major project.

nonEnforcedPrerequisites: Minimum 3.0 CS GPA or instructor's consent.

description: Foundational topics in verification and validation; the application of logic to building correct systems. Covers logics to formally specify properties of systems, verifications of basic systems, and advanced topics in formal verification for complex systems.
name: Verification and Validation

learningOutcomes.name: Formally reason about concurrent systems and executions
learningOutcomes.objective: Formally reason about concurrent systems and executions

learningOutcomes.name: Define correctness in concurrent systems
learningOutcomes.objective: Define basic correctness principles of concurrent systems including deadlock, live-lock, safety, and general liveness.

learningOutcomes.name: Analyze concurrent objects for correctness
learningOutcomes.objective: Use tools to analyze concurrent objects for correctness and performance

learningOutcomes.name: Learn best-practices for spin locks and monitors
learningOutcomes.objective: Learn best-practices for spin locks and monitors

learningOutcomes.name: Discuss wait-free versus lock-free implementations
learningOutcomes.objective: Compare and contrast wait-free and lock-free properties in concurrent objects

learningOutcomes.name: Understand and use concurrent data structures
learningOutcomes.objective: Understand and use concurrent data structures

learningOutcomes.name: Correctly use barriers and fences
learningOutcomes.objective: Correctly use barriers and fences

learningOutcomes.name: Have working knowledge of tools and techniques for testing c
learningOutcomes.objective: Have working knowledge of tools and techniques for testing concurrent programs

learningOutcomes.name: Be familiar to libraries to support concurrent programming i
learningOutcomes.objective: Be familiar to libraries to support concurrent programming in C, C , C#, and Java

learningOutcomes.name: Describe future trends in multi-processor programming
learningOutcomes.objective: Describe future trends in multi-processor programming

description: Students work in teams to prepare for and compete in computer science competitions in areas such as programming, data science, and ethical hacking.
name: Computing Competitions
nonEnforcedPrerequisites: Minimum 3.0 C S GPA or instructor's consent.

description: Culminating experience based on skills learned in advanced technical courses. Students work in teams to plan, design, test, and demonstrate a major project.
name: Capstone 1

learningOutcomes.name: Students will design and implement software
learningOutcomes.objective: Culminating experience based on skills learned in advanced technical courses. Students work in teams to plan, design, implement, test, and demonstrate a major project.

nonEnforcedPrerequisites: Minimum 3.0 CS GPA or instructor's consent.

description: The second semester of a culminating experience based on skills learned in advanced technical courses. Students work in teams to plan, design, test, and demonstrate a major project.
name: Capstone 2

learningOutcomes.name: Students will design and implement software
learningOutcomes.objective: Culminating experience based on skills learned in advanced technical courses. Students work in teams to plan, design, implement, test, and demonstrate a major project.

nonEnforcedPrerequisites: Minimum 3.0 CS GPA or instructor's consent.

description: Students receive course credit for doing undergraduate research under the supervision of a faculty mentor.
name: Undergraduate Research

learningOutcomes.name: Students will gain research skills
learningOutcomes.objective: Students work in a laboratory and develop research skills

nonEnforcedPrerequisites: Students must turn in signed research agreement at least 1 business day before add/drop deadline in order to receive permission-to-add code. Research agreement form can be found at http://cs.byu.edu or in the CS Department office.

description: Students identify an interesting problem in computer science and solve it with the aid of faculty members.
name: Undergraduate Special Projects
note: If taken for less than 3 credits this course may not count as a CS elective. See approval form on the CS Department web site at https://cs.byu.edu/. Project proposals must be submitted by the last day of class of the prior semester or term. Students are allowed 1 repeat of each CS undergraduate course (all 100-, 200-, 300- or 400-level courses). This includes all students who received any grade including those who withdraw (receive a "W" grade) from a CS course. Students must wait 1 semester/term before being allowed to take a course they have failed twice. Petitions for exceptions to the policy can be completed at cs.byu.edu/undergraduate-handbook/retake-policy-cs-courses/.

learningOutcomes.name: Capstone Experience in a Special Topic
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will propose, execute, and report a capstone project in an area that they choose in consultation with a professor. Each project is approved by the Undergraduate Curriculum Committee.

description: Introduction for science, math, and statistics majors to careers in industry. Project planning, oral and written business presentations, business accounting, and technology readiness.
long_name: (C S-Chem-Geol-Math-MthEd-Phscs-Stat) Business Career Essentials in Science and Math
name: Business Career Essentials

learningOutcomes.name: Project Management
learningOutcomes.objective: Learn the basics of project management and understand why this is important to business success

learningOutcomes.name: Business Presentations and Writing
learningOutcomes.objective: Learn the basics of effective business presentations and writing

learningOutcomes.name: Technology Readiness
learningOutcomes.objective: Understand the different levels of technology readiness and the process of moving a project through these levels to completion

description: Advanced undergraduate- and graduate-level subjects as announced before each semester.
name: Adv Topics in Computer Sci

learningOutcomes.name: Advanced topic in Computer Science
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will learn a topic in Computer Science not covered by the regular curriculum.

nonEnforcedPrerequisites: Instructor's consent

description: Course will assist graduating students in identifying and connecting to potential employers.
name: Job Search Strategies

description: Introduction to the analysis and design of feedback systems guaranteed to perform well in spite of model uncertainty.
name: Robust Control

learningOutcomes.name: LMIs
learningOutcomes.objective: Understand Linear Matrix Inequalities and their role in various identification and control problems.

learningOutcomes.name: Systems Concepts
learningOutcomes.objective: Understand system concepts of stability, controllability, observability, minimality, behavior, and structure.

learningOutcomes.name: Representation
learningOutcomes.objective: Understand various mathematical representations of systems.

learningOutcomes.name: Four Basic Problems
learningOutcomes.objective: Understand the four basic problems: Model Reduction (i.e. Approximation), System Identification (i.e. Learning), Control (i.e. Decision Making), and Verification/Validation, and how they impact each other.

learningOutcomes.name: Hankel Singular Values
learningOutcomes.objective: Understand Hankel singular values and their role in balanced truncation as an approximation to optimal model reduction.

learningOutcomes.name: Small Gain
learningOutcomes.objective: Understand the role of the Small Gain Theorem and Passivity in providing guarantees of algorithm correctness in spite of model uncertainty.

recommended: C S 312 and 412; Math 334; or equivalents

description: Understand and use qualitative and quantitative methods for human-computer interaction research, such as interviews, observations, surveys, and measurements. Learn to choose study designs, analyze data, and consider ethical implications of involving human participants in research.
long_name: Research Methods and Study Design in Human-Computer Interaction
name: Research Methods in HCI

learningOutcomes.name: Research Methodologies
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will be able to choose between qualitative and quantitative research methods in human-computer interaction.

learningOutcomes.name: Logical Approaches
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will be able to choose between inductive and deductive research methods in human-computer interaction.

learningOutcomes.name: Decision-Making
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will be able to discuss decisions made in research study design.

learningOutcomes.name: Ethical Compliance
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will be able to successfully navigate the institutional review board application process to ensure research compliance.

learningOutcomes.name: Method Assessment
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will critically assess study methods presented in published peer-reviewed HCI research.

nonEnforcedPrerequisites: Prior experience in user experience or human-computer interaction.

description: Understand and learn how to use state of the art transformer language models for many Natural Language Processing and Understanding tasks, such as text classification, text generation, question answering, machine translation, and many other tasks.
long_name: Transformer Models for Natural Language Processing
name: Transformers for NLP

learningOutcomes.name: Transformer Model
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will study and demonstrate understanding of the transformer model and multi-headed attention mechanisms.

learningOutcomes.name: Transformers for NLP
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will demonstrate understanding and develop code that uses transformer models for many Natural Language Processing tasks such as text classification, named entity recognition, question answering, and summarization.

learningOutcomes.name: Generative Models
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will develop generative transformer models to generate appropriate text for a project of their choice.

learningOutcomes.name: Zero Shot and Few Shot Learning
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will demonstrate understanding of zero shot and few shot learning and prompt engineering for generative models.

learningOutcomes.name: Scaling
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will demonstrate understanding of scaling methods for large language models such as distillation, quantization, as well as methods for training models with small amounts of training data.

description: Use graph structures to explore labeled data and discover network relationships within the data. Understand network relationships, learn graph models of common network structures, identify network communities and influential members, and work with knowledge graphs.
name: Intro to Graph Data Science

learningOutcomes.objective: Students will be able to implement and use Barabasi-Albert, Watts-Strogatz, Erdos-Renyi, and affiliation network-based algorithms.

Students will be able to implement and use graph theory concepts applicable to networks: adjacency matrix, adjacency matrix, adjacency lists, graph Laplacian, algebraic connectivity, spectral graph properties.
Students will implement and understand how information and disease spread/diffuse over a network: simple contagion and complex contagion/diffusion of innovations.
Students will apply graph metrics to understand diffusion dynamics: clustering, density, diameter, algebraic connectivity, degree distribution, distance, modularity, assortativity.
Students will be able to implement agent-based models over networks.
Students will be able to mitigate/promote network effects by identifying communities, removing edges, adding edges, choosing early adopters.

nonEnforcedPrerequisites: Linear Algebra

description: Mathematical, computational, and philosophical foundations of machine learning, control, and physical modeling.  Introduction to system identification, causality, uncertainty, model approximation, and information geometry.
name: Theory of Predictive Modeling

description: Fundamentals of modeling, texturing, lighting, and rendering used in exploring principles and elements of three-dimensional design.
name: Intro to 3D Graphics
courseTypicallyOffered: Fall Term 1; Fall Term 2; Winter Term 1; Winter Term 2.
note: For Pre-Computer Science: Animation and Games, and Pre-Animation Majors ONLY

learningOutcomes.name: Technical Proficiency
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will be able to use Maya at a basic level of familiarity and demonstrate basic capability in modeling, texturing, lighting, and rendering.

learningOutcomes.name: Artistic proficiency in 3-Dimensions
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will be able to make visually interesting and readable images.

description: This class teaches foundational skills that animation students require when working in a shot-based production environment. Cinematography, layout, composition and storytelling techniques will be a focus of study.
name: Visual Narrative

learningOutcomes.name: Shot Making
learningOutcomes.objective: The ability to critique, discuss and create film narrative in the continuity style of film making heavily used in animation.

learningOutcomes.name: Color, Lighting & Composition for film
learningOutcomes.objective: Acquire a foundational level of understanding of color, lighting and composition for film. Be able to critique, discuss, and improve layouts for animation.

learningOutcomes.name: Crew & Professional Dynamics:
learningOutcomes.objective: Learn how animated productions are structured and how departments work together in a Visual Effects or Animation Porduction

learningOutcomes.name: Narrative
learningOutcomes.objective: Demonstrate ability to tell a visual story with an emphasis on clarity, structure and delivery.

description: Fundaments of building three-dimensional computer models and setting up model rigs for mobility.
name: Interm 3D Computer Graphics
note: Course changed to CSAnm 250 beginning Fall 2012.

learningOutcomes.name: 3D Computer Graphics
learningOutcomes.objective: Create 3D Computer Graphics

description: Foundational principles and techniques of three-dimensional animation, including timing and pacing,  character setup, and dynamics.
name: Intro 3D Animation
note: Course changed to CSAnm 252 beginning Fall 2012.

learningOutcomes.name: Technical Proficiency
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will be able to animate in Maya using key frames, blend shapes, and character rigs.

learningOutcomes.name: Appealing 3D Animation
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will be able to translate the twelve principles of animation into 3-dimensional space.

learningOutcomes.name: Self-analysis as an Animator
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will be able to identify personal weaknesses in animation and analyze paths to turn those into strengths.

description: Developing basic scripting skills to procedurally build intricate systems of models, rigs, and animation.  Students learn how to reduce manual hours and efficiently create simple to complex effects.
name: Scripting for Animation
note: Course changed to CSAnm 258 beginning Fall 2014.

learningOutcomes.name: Scripting Skills
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will be able to code in animation environments, using both Python and Houdini, build procedural environments and animate parameters using scripting expressions, and procedurally build intricate systems of models, rigs, and animation through basic coding and node-based scripting skills.

learningOutcomes.name: Increased Efficiency in Animation
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will be able to efficiently create both simple and complex effects with less effort as well as automate modeling, rigging, and animation processes so that intricate animation systems can be completed in a practical, timely manner.

description: This is an introductory elective course in game design.  We will cover foundational game elements and the processes for designing game experiences. These principles are ubiquitously foundational to all parts of the video game development pipeline. This class helps students develop understanding and intuition for the techniques that make gameplay and accompanying worlds successful. \n
name: Game Design

learningOutcomes.name: Game Design
learningOutcomes.objective: Design a computer game

description: This class introduces students to real-time applications. It provides principles foundational for creating video games and other real-time media. Students learn how to mock up basic game mechanics in a realtime engine, such as Unreal Engine, and create basic environments and characters for a real time engine. This is meant to be an introduction to a variety of skills that students can take further and deeper on future projects.
name: Real-time Techniques

learningOutcomes.name: Real Time Technologies
learningOutcomes.objective: Use real time technologies

nonEnforcedPrerequisites: CS Animation Emphasis Majors or Animation Majors; or instructor's consent

description: Developing lighting and color, and the compiling of the various elements for final images for use in three-dimensional applications.
name: Lighting for 3D Graphics
note: Course changed to CSAnm 351R beginning Fall 2012.

learningOutcomes.name: Application
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will learn and apply the skills of lighting for 3D graphics.

description: Early development of a film, including character design, environments, pipeline, visual effects, and the look and feel the film. All pre-visualization of the film. Practice collaborative production processes through interdisciplinary creative works or experiences.
name: Animated Film Production 1

learningOutcomes.name: Pre-production
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will contribute to pre-production on a film using modeling, effects, animation, and other conceptual methods as well as work through design, story, and production pipeline issues.

learningOutcomes.name: Visual effects
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will contribute to visual effects proof of concept through pre-visualization, pipeline development, visual development, and modeling during pre-production.

description: This class teaches the art and technical aspects of previsualization using 3D software and cameras. This technique is crucial to the modern filmmaking process, and students will learn the process through principles and experience.
name: Previsualization

learningOutcomes.name: Previsualization
learningOutcomes.objective: Effective use of previsualization.

description: Shading and rendering techniques for the attainment of desired visual effects:  use of shading languages for the realization of both photorealistic and non-photorealistic imaging.
name: Materials and Surfacing
note: Course changed to CSAnm 354 beginning Fall 2012.

learningOutcomes.name: Technical Proficiency
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will be able to create shaders and understand how shading fits into a production pipeline. Students will have the ability to implement technical, programmatic, and mathematical under-the-hood principles used to generate procedural patterns, displacements, and surface models.

learningOutcomes.name: Matching Visual Direction
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will be able to light and surface objects with color patterns, displacement, surface models, and lighting to match already lit live-action scenes. Students will be able to manage technical and artistic aspects of shading and rendering techniques for creating art-directable surface textures for computer-generated (CG) visual effects and animated films.

description: Layout, references, camera technology and terminology, application of composition, lighting, and core art skills emphasized.
name: Photography for Animation
