note: Course changed to CSAnm 355 beginning Fall 2012.

learningOutcomes.name: Practices and artistry
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will understand and be able to use current technologies to transfer information from digital photography to animation artifacts.  Students will understand how artistic requirements inform when and how to use photography to support animation.

description: In-depth experiences creating computer animations and visual effects.  Senior film front-end development and introduction to full animation production.
name: Animated Film Production 2
note: Course changed to CSAnm 450 beginning Fall 2012.

learningOutcomes.name: Dynamic Roles in Production
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will be able to contribute to the production of an animated film by specializing in visual effects, shaders/surfacing, compositing, rendering, lighting, editing, pipeline development, animation, or a combination of these.

learningOutcomes.name: Collaboration, Synergy, and Compromise
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will be able to align their efforts to the art direction, story direction, audio, and production constraints of an animated project. Students will also be able to collaborate with a diverse team and work through the unexpected challenges working with a team creates on an animated film.

description: Portfolio development based on advanced animation/design projects. Senior film production and post production.
name: Animated Film Production 3
note: Course changed to CSAnm 452R beginning Fall 2012.

learningOutcomes.name: Polish and Publish
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will be able to apply the skills necessary to finish off and publish a senior film, including rendering, compositing, and audio, as well as solve complicated last-minute problems on a project, both individually and collaboratively.

learningOutcomes.name: Marketing Materials
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will be able to work together to create publicity and supplemental materials for a film project.

description: Researching new technologies in animation and visualization.  Topics might include real-time technologies, three-dimensional data acquisition, performance capture, or new entertainment platforms.
name: Topics in Advanced Graphics
note: Course changed to CSAnm 453R beginning Fall 2012.

learningOutcomes.name: Emerging graphics practices
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will be able to implement, apply, and extend state-of-the-art practices in computer graphics relevant for animation.

description: Advanced shading, rendering, and lighting methods for creating virtual scenes that emphasize story and innovatively meet an art director's vision through traditional and procedural methods.
name: Advanced Shading
note: Course changed to CSAnm 454 beginning Fall 2012.

learningOutcomes.name: Practice and artistry of shading
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will understand the artistic importance and subtleties of shading, and be able to implement/extend state-of-the-art practices in shading for animation.

description: Exploring procedural and three-dimensional animation methods to create realistic special effects.  Applying a large spectrum of animation principles to integrate their effects aesthetically and convincingly into a live action or animated environment.
name: 3D Visual Effects
note: Course changed to CSAnm 458 beginning Fall 2012.

learningOutcomes.name: Effects Creation
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will be able to model, animate, light, and composite virtual environmental effects and character effects such as fire, smoke, water, and so forth.

learningOutcomes.name: Artistry in Technical Achievement
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will be able to balance the artistry and technical aspects of visual effects in film.

learningOutcomes.name: 3D with a 2D Foundation
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will be able to apply their knowledge of hand-drawn effects to create effects within a 3D environmental context and merge characters into their story and environment.

description: Using prototyping to develop game experience ideas by building a minimal viable product around a core experience idea. Participating in a team and coordinating tasks, including white-boxing, concept design, modeling, layout, rigging, and tool building.
name: Video Game Production 1

learningOutcomes.name: Collaboration
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will also be able to collaborate with a diverse team and work through the unexpected challenges that come with working on a team.

learningOutcomes.name: Collaboration, Synergy, and Compromise
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will be able to align their efforts to the art direction, gameplay experience, audio, and production constraints of a video game project

learningOutcomes.name: Dynamic Roles in Production
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will contribute to the production of an interactive video game by specializing in real-time visual effects, animation, shaders/surfacing, lighting, gameplay prototyping, pipeline development, user interfaces, feedback signaling, or a combination of these.

nonEnforcedPrerequisites: Junior or senior status.

description: Polishing a video game for production as a team, including texturing, animation, FX, lighting, tool applications, AI, UI, and gameplay mechanics.
name: Video Game Production 2

learningOutcomes.name: Dynamic Roles in Production
learningOutcomes.objective: Students learn production and post-production skills by polishing and completing a full slice (level or stage) of their game. This includes a major focus on playtesting and applying user feedback in an iterative process. Students apply and polish the principles of game feedback and game balance.

learningOutcomes.name: Collaboration, Synergy, and Compromise
learningOutcomes.objective: Students divide up tasks including animation, modeling, lighting, FX, user interface, music, and sound, and learn to coordinate their respective roles in the greater context of the game.

nonEnforcedPrerequisites: Junior or senior status.

description: Individual study in area of special interest.
name: Special Problems in Animation
note: Course changed to CSAnm 494R beginning Fall 2012.

learningOutcomes.name: Application
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will solve special problems in animation.

nonEnforcedPrerequisites: Instructor's consent.

description: Advanced individual project with minimum guidance, showing high degree of competence within chosen major.
name: BFA Final Project
note: Course changed to CSAnm 497R beginning Fall 2012.

learningOutcomes.name: Application
learningOutcomes.objective: Students will complete a BFA final project.

nonEnforcedPrerequisites: BFA advisor's consent.

description: statistics; linear algebra; machine learning; data cleaning and visualization; data literacy; decomposing data science problems; critical thinking about analysis; potential pitfalls in data science
name: Intro to Data Science
nonEnforcedPrerequisites: CS 110 or equivalent prior programming experience
recommended: Prior programming experience should include statements, variables, control flow (if/while), and functions
